qas.question: What is a symptom of LED failure?
What is rare in LED lighting?
What was notable in early red LEDs?
What could cause early light-output degradation in LEDs?
What is a classification used in LED lighting to describe how much usefulness it will receive?
What is a symptom of non-LED failure?
What is rare in non-LED lighting?
What was notable in early white LEDs?
What could cause early light-output degradation in non-LEDs?
What is a classification used in non-LED lighting to describe how much usefulness it will receive?

context: The most common symptom of LED (and diode laser) failure is the gradual lowering of light output and <a0_0><b5_0>loss of efficiency<b5_0/><a0_0/>. <a1_0><b6_0>Sudden failures<b6_0/><a1_0/>, although rare, can also occur. Early red LEDs were notable for <a2_0>their <b7_0>short service life<b7_0/><a2_0/>. With the development of high-power LEDs the devices are subjected to <a3_0><b8_0>higher junction temperatures<b8_0/><a3_0/> and higher current densities than traditional devices. This causes stress on the material and may cause early light-output degradation. To quantitatively classify useful lifetime in a standardized manner it has been suggested to use <a4_0><b9_0>L70 or L50<b9_0/><a4_0/>, which are the runtimes (typically given in thousands of hours) at which a given LED reaches 70% and 50% of initial light output, respectively.
